verses.text: These also are proverbs of Solomon, the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied them:
verses.comment: This verse introduces a collected body of Solomon's proverbs preserved under royal authority. The transmission through Hezekiah’s scribes highlights both the importance of tradition and the community’s role in preserving wisdom.

verses.text: It is the glory of God to conceal a matter, but the glory of kings is to search a matter out.
verses.comment: This verse shows the mystery and majesty of God’s wisdom, which sometimes remains hidden. Leaders are called to pursue truth diligently. In Christian theology, this seeking finds fulfillment in Christ, who fully reveals the Father (see Jn 1:18).

verses.text: As the heavens are high and the earth is deep, so the heart of kings is unsearchable.
verses.comment: Just as it is difficult to fathom the heights and depths of creation, so the motivations of those in authority can be beyond human understanding. This highlights the value of both humility and trust in God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: Remove the dross from the silver, and a vessel for the smith will emerge;
verses.comment: This is a picture of purification. Removing impurities prepares something for noble use. Spiritually, God purifies His people through discipline, drawing them to greater holiness (Heb 12:10).

verses.text: Remove the wicked from the presence of the king, and his throne will be established in righteousness.
verses.comment: Just as silver must be purified, so must leadership be protected from evil influences. This theme of cleansing the community for right worship and governance recurs throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Do not exalt yourself in the king’s presence, or stand in the place of the great;
verses.comment: This verse anticipates Jesus’ parable about humility at the banquet (Lk 14:8-11). Humble self-placement is honored in God’s kingdom, emphasizing spiritual meekness.

verses.text: For it is better to be told, "Come up here," than to be put lower in the presence of a nobleman you saw.
verses.comment: True honor is received, not taken. Christ himself embodied this humility (Phil 2:8-9), teaching that exaltation comes from God, not earthly striving.

verses.text: Do not be quick to go to court, for what will you do in the end, when your neighbor puts you to shame?
verses.comment: This warning against hasty litigation finds echo in Jesus' teaching (Mt 5:25). Patience and reconciliation are higher virtues than vindictiveness.

verses.text: Argue your case with your neighbor himself, and do not disclose another’s secret;
verses.comment: Private confrontation, not public shaming, is encouraged. This principle runs throughout both Old and New Testaments, promoting unity and trust within the community.

verses.text: Lest the one who hears you bring shame upon you, and your bad reputation never goes away.
verses.comment: Reputations are lasting. A just and charitable approach to disputes preserves honor and communal peace.

verses.text: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold in settings of silver.
verses.comment: Beautiful imagery emphasizes the power and value of wise, timely speech. Wisdom is seen as precious and nourishing for the community.

verses.text: Like a gold ring or an ornament of fine gold is a wise reprover to a listening ear.
verses.comment: Constructive correction is a rare treasure—it brings benefit and adornment to the humble listener.

verses.text: Like the cold of snow at harvest time is a faithful messenger to those who send him; he refreshes his master’s soul.
verses.comment: Faithfulness and reliability are prized, bringing much-needed refreshment—just as Christ is the faithful messenger of the Father, bringing true peace (Jn 20:21).

verses.text: Like clouds and wind without rain is a man who boasts of gifts he does not give.
verses.comment: Empty promises are as disappointing as clouds without needed rain. Sincerity is key to both human and spiritual relationships.

verses.text: With patience a ruler may be persuaded, and a gentle tongue breaks a bone.
verses.comment: Persistence, coupled with gentleness, achieves what force cannot. True spiritual authority is exercised in humility and patience.

verses.text: If you find honey, eat only what you need, lest you have too much and vomit it.
verses.comment: Even good things can become harmful in excess. Self-control is a timeless biblical value (Gal 5:23).

verses.text: Let your foot seldom be in your neighbor’s house, or he will become weary of you and hate you.
verses.comment: Healthy boundaries preserve relationships. Too much familiarity leads to contempt and disharmony.

verses.text: A man who bears false witness against his neighbor is like a club, a sword, and a sharp arrow.
verses.comment: False witness is compared to deadly weapons. Truthfulness is essential to personal and communal righteousness (Eph 4:25).

verses.text: Trusting in a treacherous person in time of trouble is like a bad tooth or a foot out of joint.
verses.comment: Unfaithful friends are unreliable when most needed. Ultimately, only God is an unfailing source of help.

verses.text: Like one who takes off a garment on a cold day, or vinegar poured on soda, is one who sings songs to a heavy heart.
verses.comment: Insensitive cheer is as damaging as being exposed to the cold. Sympathy and empathy are virtues constantly praised and commanded in Christian love.

verses.text: If your enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat, and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink;
verses.comment: This command to love enemies is referenced directly by Paul (Rom 12:20) and embodied perfectly by Christ (Mt 5:44). It anticipates the radical nature of Gospel love.

verses.text: for you will heap burning coals on his head, and the Lord will reward you.
verses.comment: Returning good for evil brings shame to the wrongdoer and merits divine reward—pointing toward Christ’s teaching that mercy triumphs over judgment (Jas 2:13).

verses.text: The north wind brings forth rain, and a backbiting tongue brings angry looks.
verses.comment: Gossip stirs up strife as surely as the wind brings rain. Peaceful community life depends on bridling the tongue (Jas 3:6).

verses.text: It is better to live in a corner of the housetop than in a house shared with a contentious woman.
verses.comment: Harmony at home brings peace. Discord, even in comfortable circumstances, is miserable and destructive.

verses.text: Like cold water to a weary soul is good news from a distant land.
verses.comment: Good news, ultimately fulfilled in the Gospel, brings hope and restoration, like Christ who is the Living Water (Jn 4:14).

verses.text: Like a muddied spring or a polluted fountain is a righteous man who gives way before the wicked.
verses.comment: Compromised righteousness is spiritually damaging, affecting many. Perseverance in truth and virtue, even in adversity, is essential (see Mt 5:13).

verses.text: It is not good to eat too much honey, nor is it glorious to seek one’s own glory.
verses.comment: Glory-seeking, like gluttony, corrupts the soul. Humility is the path to lasting honor (see Lk 14:11).

verses.text: A man without self-control is like a city broken into and left without walls.
verses.comment: Self-control is vital protection for both the soul and community. The biblical tradition understands virtue as both gift and human response, cultivated through grace and discipline.
